name: Naloxone (Narcan)
summary: An opioid antagonist used to rapidly reverse opioid overdose.
description: Naloxone is a pure opioid antagonist that competitively binds to opioid receptors, displacing opioid molecules and reversing their effects. It is most commonly used in emergency situations to treat life-threatening respiratory depression due to opioid overdose. It can be administered intranasally, intramuscularly, subcutaneously, or intravenously.

metadata.prescription_status: Varies by jurisdiction (often OTC for intranasal formulations)

contraindications: Known hypersensitivity to naloxone or formulation components

sections.text: Naloxone binds with high affinity to mu-opioid receptors, displacing opioid molecules and reversing their respiratory and CNS depressant effects.

adult.intranasal: 4 mg (one spray) in one nostril; repeat every 2–3 minutes as needed, alternating nostrils
adult.intramuscular_intravenous_subcutaneous: 0.4–2 mg every 2–3 minutes as needed (max total dose 10 mg)

sections.pediatric: Same dosing as adults; may use weight-based dosing if preferred for IV/IM

sections.text: Onset within 2–5 minutes intranasally or 1–2 minutes intravenously; duration 30–90 minutes depending on route.

other: Effects may wear off before the opioid has fully cleared; repeated dosing may be necessary
Can precipitate severe withdrawal in opioid-dependent individuals

items.action: Only use for overdose or toxicity

sections.pregnancy: Category B; use if benefits outweigh risks
sections.lactation: Minimal transfer to breast milk; generally considered safe
sections.pediatrics: Safe and effective; dose as in adults

items: Educate patients and caregivers on recognition of opioid overdose
Provide training on proper administration technique
Call emergency services immediately after use

seo.title: Naloxone (Narcan): Opioid Overdose Reversal Guide
seo.description: Naloxone (Narcan) is an opioid antagonist used to reverse opioid overdoses rapidly and effectively.
